questions.prompt: In BG 15.1, how is the material world compared, and how are its roots and branches described?
choices: A tree with sideways roots and upward branches
An inverted banyan, roots up, branches down
A normal banyan, roots below, branches above
A banyan with roots and branches level
questions.feedback: Krsna compares the material world to an inverted banyan tree, with roots upward and branches downward. The image emphasizes that this world is dependent on a higher source and is a reflection, not the original reality.

questions.prompt: According to BG 15.2, what role do the modes of nature and fruitive work play in the expansion of the banyan tree?
choices: Bhakti grows branches; detachment grows roots
Modes cut branches; jnana cuts the roots
Time alone expands both roots and branches
Modes feed branches; karma grows the roots
questions.feedback: Krsna explains that the branches are nourished by the three modes of material nature, while the roots grow through fruitive activities. This shows how modes and karma together sustain bondage.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 15.1, what essential point does Srila Prabhupada stress about the banyan-tree analogy?
choices: It is a perverted reflection, not the original
It proves matter is final and self-sufficient
It is the spiritual world in literal form
It is poetry, not philosophical teaching
questions.feedback: Prabhupada emphasizes that the banyan tree represents a perverted reflection of reality. Mistaking the reflection for the original leads one to cling to material complexity instead of seeking the true source.

questions.prompt: According to BG 15.3, what is said about perceiving the true form, beginning, and end of the banyan tree?
choices: Ritual alone reveals its complete structure
Its foundation is seen clearly in this world
Its true form and limits are not seen here
Its form is obvious because it is the soul
questions.feedback: Krsna states that the true form of the tree, along with its beginning and end, is not perceived here. This underlines the inadequacy of material perception for understanding ultimate reality.

questions.prompt: According to BG 15.3-4, what action should one take regarding the banyan tree, and by what means?
choices: Cut it with detachment and seek the abode
Ignore it until it fades by time alone
Balance it by regulated enjoyment and virtue
Study it deeply by speculative reasoning
questions.feedback: Krsna instructs that the tree should be cut down with the weapon of detachment, after which one should seek the supreme abode. Detachment removes false shelter so true shelter can be found.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 15.4, which attitude best illustrates the false form of detachment that Srila Prabhupada warns against?
choices: I follow rules to gain steadiness and clarity
I renounce outwardly but plan enjoyment inside
I reduce indulgence to serve Krsna better
I avoid prestige so devotion stays central
questions.feedback: Prabhupada warns against superficial detachment that hides continued desire for enjoyment. Such renunciation changes appearance but not the center of identity, leaving bondage intact.

questions.prompt: According to BG 15.5, which qualities characterize those who reach the eternal destination?
choices: Rich in honor, learning, and refined comfort
Free from false prestige, steady beyond duality
Powerful in politics with social protection
Strong in ritual skill and austere pride
questions.feedback: Krsna lists freedom from false prestige and illusion, detachment, and steadiness beyond dualities. The emphasis is purification of identity, not elevation within material hierarchy.

questions.prompt: In BG 15.6, what is said about the supreme abode in relation to light and return?
choices: It depends on sun; return is guaranteed
It equals heaven gained by pious work
It is self-luminous; return does not occur
It lasts only for one cosmic age
questions.feedback: The supreme abode requires no sun, moon, or fire, and one who reaches it never returns. This distinguishes eternal shelter from temporary elevation.

questions.prompt: According to BG 15.7, what is the constitutional position of the jiva, and what struggle does it face in material nature?
choices: A non-self, produced by ignorance and words
A fragmental part, struggling with mind and senses
An equal controller, struggling by imagination alone
A product of matter, struggling only with the body
questions.feedback: The jiva is an eternal fragmental part of Krsna and struggles with the six senses, including the mind. The struggle arises from misidentification, not from loss of existence.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 15.7, which distinction prevents the mistaken idea that the jiva becomes the Supreme?
choices: Becomes supreme by perfecting knowledge alone
Same quality, never the Lord's unlimited quantity
Is created in time and therefore not real
Dissolves into Brahman and loses individuality
questions.feedback: Prabhupada stresses that although the jiva shares spiritual quality with Krsna, it never becomes the unlimited whole. Confusing part with controller blocks surrender.

questions.prompt: According to BG 15.8, how does the living entity transition from one body to another?
choices: Carries mind and senses, like air carries scent
Transfers by rituals performed by others only
Dissolves into matter, then reforms as a new self
Loses all continuity and becomes a new being
questions.feedback: The soul carries mind and senses to the next body, just as air carries aromas. This explains continuity of desire and conditioning across lifetimes.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 15.8, what practical lesson is emphasized for spiritual advancement?
choices: Memory loss cancels the effects of practice
Mind cannot be trained, so effort is minor
External conduct alone determines future progress
Conditioning follows the soul; purify inner habits
questions.feedback: Prabhupada emphasizes that desires and conditioning follow the soul, so purification must be internal. Otherwise the same identity is simply transferred to a new body.

questions.prompt: According to BG 15.9, how does the living entity attempt to enjoy the material world?
choices: Through mind and senses, tasting sense objects
By remaining untouched by any perception
By spiritual bliss alone, beyond all perception
By shutting down experience as the final goal
questions.feedback: The jiva attempts to enjoy sense objects through the mind and senses. This mechanism explains how enjoyment-seeking reinforces bondage.

questions.prompt: According to BG 15.10, who can truly understand the soul's presence and departure?
choices: Those with sharp logic and debating skill
Those indifferent to discipline and practice
Those with eyes of knowledge, not the foolish
Those seeking material gain as their goal
questions.feedback: Krsna explains that those with eyes of knowledge can understand these truths, while the foolish cannot. Purified perception, not argument, is required.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 15.10-11, what false assumption about spiritual vision is rejected?
choices: Discipline helps devotional steadiness over time
Realization is automatic without purification or method
Hearing guides understanding and conviction slowly
Regulation supports clarity and seriousness
questions.feedback: Prabhupada rejects the idea that realization is cheap or automatic. Genuine vision follows purification, method, and submissive hearing.

questions.prompt: According to BG 15.12, what is the source of the splendor of the sun, moon, and fire?
choices: Their splendor comes from Krsna
Their splendor comes only from demigods
Their splendor is independent by natural law
Their splendor arises only from sacrifice
questions.feedback: Krsna states that the splendor of sun, moon, and fire comes from Him. Visible power is traced back to its personal source.

questions.prompt: According to BG 15.13, how does Krsna sustain the universe?
choices: He sustains by constant destruction and reset
He stays distant and uninvolved after creation
He delegates all maintenance to demigods
He enters planets and supports them by His energy
questions.feedback: Krsna explains that He enters and sustains the worlds through His energy. Maintenance is ongoing dependence, not independence.

questions.prompt: According to BG 15.14, what role does Krsna describe Himself as playing within living beings?
choices: The mind that produces imagination and doubt
The ego that generates pride and rivalry
Digestive fire that processes four kinds of food
The senses that create attachment and craving
questions.feedback: Krsna says He becomes the fire of digestion. Even ordinary bodily processes operate by His arrangement.

questions.prompt: According to BG 15.15, what comes from Krsna, and what is the Vedas' ultimate purpose?
choices: Remembrance, knowledge, forgetfulness; to know Him
Ritual success; to gain heaven and merit
Liberation alone; to negate personality
Ethics and prosperity; to regulate society
questions.feedback: Krsna says remembrance, knowledge, and forgetfulness come from Him, and that all the Vedas aim to know Him. He is both their source and conclusion.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 15.15, how does Prabhupada explain continuity of activity despite forgetfulness?
choices: The soul resumes work by the Lord's sanction and guidance
The soul remembers everything and needs no help
Activity is random and has no continuity
Nature alone directs intelligence and memory
questions.feedback: Prabhupada explains that although the soul forgets past details, it resumes activity under the Lord's sanction, receiving intelligence as needed.

questions.prompt: According to BG 15.16, what two categories of living beings are identified?
choices: Renounced and householders
Liberated and condemned
Learned and unlearned
Fallible and infallible
questions.feedback: Krsna identifies two categories of beings: fallible and infallible. This prepares the ground for identifying the Supreme beyond both.

questions.prompt: According to BG 15.17, who is described as the Supreme Person?
choices: A demigod who manages one universe temporarily
The combined jivas acting as one controller
An impersonal absolute that does not act
The Lord who enters and sustains all worlds
questions.feedback: BG 15.17 describes the Supreme Person who enters and sustains the worlds. Ultimate reality is active, personal, and sustaining.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 15.18, what mistaken stopping-point is explicitly rejected?
choices: Service as essential for fulfillment
Surrender as necessary for liberation
Impersonal realization as final, minimizing the Person
Devotion as the mature conclusion of knowledge
questions.feedback: Prabhupada warns against stopping at impersonal realization. Chapter 15 insists that the Supreme Person is the ultimate conclusion of knowledge.

questions.prompt: Synthesis (BG 15.1-6): What is the correct movement from diagnosis to cure?
choices: Reject all action and remain inactive as the cure
Balance the modes so the reflection becomes stable
Diagnose the reflection, cut false shelter, seek the abode
Study the reflection until satisfaction naturally arises
questions.feedback: The chapter diagnoses the material world as an inverted reflection and prescribes the cure: cut false shelter through detachment and seek the original abode beyond it.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 15.20, what does Srila Prabhupada define as true fulfillment?
choices: Rise beyond good and evil by indifference
Perfect material duty as the final goal
Win debates and gain philosophical prestige
Conclude correctly about Krsna and serve Him in bhakti
questions.feedback: Prabhupada explains that fulfillment means arriving at the right conclusion about Krsna and acting on it through devotion, which completes knowledge and ends the search for false shelter.
